doc.title: ClustalW

description.text: ClustalW is a general purpose multiple alignment program for DNA or proteins.

doc.reference: Thompson, J.D., Higgins, D.G. and Gibson, T.J. (1994) CLUSTAL W: improving the sensitivity of progressive multiple sequence alignment through sequence weighting, positions-specific gap penalties and weight matrix choice. Nucleic Acids Research, 22:4673-4680.

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
fieldset.data-formats: FASTA NBRF EMBL GCG GDE SWISSPROT
fieldset.legend: Sequences File ( a file containing several sequences ) (-infile)

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: When the sequences are aligned (all sequences have the same length and at least one sequence has at least one gap)

xhtml:div.label:
Toggle Slow/Fast pairwise alignments (-quicktree)?
Slow Fast
slow: by dynamic programming (slow but accurate)
fast: method of Wilbur and Lipman (extremely fast but approximate)
Protein or DNA (-type) Automatic Protein DNA

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Multiple alignments are carried out in 3 stages :
1) all sequences are compared to each other (pairwise alignments);
2) a dendrogram (like a phylogenetic tree) is constructed, describing the approximate groupings of the sequences by similarity (stored in a file).
3) the final multiple alignment is carried out, using the dendrogram as a guide.
Pairwise alignment parameters control the speed/sensitivity of the initial alignments.
Multiple alignment parameters control the gaps in the final multiple alignments.

xhtml:div.label: Gap opening penalty (-gapopen)
Gap extension penalty (-gapext)

No end gap separation penalty (-endgaps)?
Yes No
End gap separation treats end gaps just like internal gaps for the purposes of avoiding gaps that are too close (set by GAP SEPARATION DISTANCE above). If you turn this off, end gaps will be ignored for this purpose. This is useful when you wish to align fragments where the end gaps are not biologically meaningful.

Gap separation penalty range (-gapdist)?
Gap separation distance tries to decrease the chances of gaps being too close to each other. Gaps that are less than this distance apart are penalised more than other gaps. This does not prevent close gaps; it makes them less frequent, promoting a block-like appearance of the alignment.

Delay divergent sequences : % ident. for delay (-maxdiv)?
Delays the alignment of the most distantly related sequences until after the most closely related sequences have been aligned. The setting shows the percent identity level required to delay the addition of a sequence; sequences that are less identical than this level to any other sequences will be aligned later.
File for new guide tree (-newtree)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: You can give a previously computed tree (.dnd file) - on the same data

xhtml:div.label:
Protein weight matrix (-matrix)?
Gonnet series BLOSUM series PAM series Identity matrix
There are three 'in-built' series of weight matrices offered. Each consists of several matrices which work differently at different evolutionary distances. To see the exact details, read the documentation. Crudely, we store several matrices in memory, spanning the full range of amino acid distance (from almost identical sequences to highly divergent ones). For very similar sequences, it is best to use a strict weight matrix which only gives a high score to identities and the most favoured conservative substitutions. For more divergent sequences, it is appropriate to use 'softer' matrices which give a high score to many other frequent substitutions.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.
The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.
Negative values in matrix ? (-negative) Yes No

Residue specific gaps off (-nopgap)?
Yes No
Residue specific penalties are amino acid specific gap penalties that reduce or increase the gap opening penalties at each position in the alignment or sequence. As an example, positions that are rich in glycine are more likely to have an adjacent gap than positions that are rich in valine.
Table of residue specific gap modification factors:
A 1.13 M 1.29
C 1.13 N 0.63
D 0.96 P 0.74
E 1.31 Q 1.07
F 1.20 R 0.72
G 0.61 S 0.76
H 1.00 T 0.89
I 1.32 V 1.25
K 0.96 Y 1.00
L 1.21 W 1.23
The values are normalised around a mean value of 1.0 for H. The lower the value, the greater the chance of having an adjacent gap. These are derived from the original table of relative frequencies of gaps adjacent to each residue (12) by subtraction from 2.0.

Hydrophilic gaps off (-nohgap)?
Yes No
Hydrophilic gap penalties are used to increase the chances of a gap within a run (5 or more residues) of hydrophilic amino acids; these are likely to be loop or random coil regions where gaps are more common. The residues that are 'considered' to be hydrophilic are set by menu item 3.
Hydrophilic residues list (-hgapresidues) A R N D C Q E G H I L K M F P S T W Y V

DNA weight matrix (-dnamatrix)?
IUB CLUSTALW
1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.

Transitions weight (between 0 and 1) (-transweight)?
A weight of zero means that the transitions are scored as mismatches; a weight of 1 gives transitions the full match score. For distantly related DNA sequences, the weight should be near to zero; for closely related sequences it can be useful to assign a higher score.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These similarity scores are calculated from fast, approximate, global alignments, which are controlled by 4 parameters. 2 techniques are used to make these alignments very fast: 1) only exactly matching fragments (k-tuples) are considered; 2) only the 'best' diagonals (the ones with most k-tuple matches) are used.

xhtml:div.label:
Word size (-ktuple)?
K-TUPLE SIZE: This is the size of exactly matching fragment that is used. INCREASE for speed (max= 2 for proteins; 4 for DNA), DECREASE for sensitivity. For longer sequences (e.g. >1000 residues) you may need to increase the default.

Number of best diagonals (-topdiags)?
The number of k-tuple matches on each diagonal (in an imaginary dot-matrix plot) is calculated. Only the best ones (with most matches) are used in the alignment. This parameter specifies how many. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity.

Window around best diags (-window)?
WINDOW SIZE: This is the number of diagonals around each of the 'best' diagonals that will be used. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity

Gap penalty (-pairgap)?
This is a penalty for each gap in the fast alignments. It has little affect on the speed or sensitivity except for extreme values.
Percent or absolute score ? (-score) Percent Absolute

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These parameters do not have any affect on the speed of the alignments. They are used to give initial alignments which are then rescored to give percent identity scores. These % scores are the ones which are displayed on the screen. The scores are converted to distances for the trees.

xhtml:div.label: Gap opening penalty (-pwgapopen)
Gap extension penalty (-pwgapext)

Protein weight matrix (-pwmatrix)?
BLOSUM30 (Henikoff) Gonnet 250 PAM350 (Dayhoff) Identity matrix
The scoring table which describes the similarity of each amino acid to each other. For DNA, an identity matrix is used.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.
The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.

DNA weight matrix (-pwdnamatrix)?
IUB CLUSTALW
For DNA, a single matrix (not a series) is used. Two hard-coded matrices are available:
1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.
Output format (-output) CLUSTAL FASTA GCG GDE PHYLIP PIR/NBRF NEXUS
Output sequence numbers in the output file (for clustalw output only) (-seqnos) Yes No
Result order (-outorder) Input Aligned
Sequence alignment file name (-outfile)
Upper case (for GDE output only) (-case) Yes No

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
div.data-formats: FASTA NBRF EMBL GCG GDE SWISSPROT

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: When the sequences are aligned (all sequences have the same length and at least one sequence has at least one gap)
slow: by dynamic programming (slow but accurate)
fast: method of Wilbur and Lipman (extremely fast but approximate)

End gap separation treats end gaps just like internal gaps for the purposes of avoiding gaps that are too close (set by GAP SEPARATION DISTANCE above). If you turn this off, end gaps will be ignored for this purpose. This is useful when you wish to align fragments where the end gaps are not biologically meaningful.

Gap separation distance tries to decrease the chances of gaps being too close to each other. Gaps that are less than this distance apart are penalised more than other gaps. This does not prevent close gaps; it makes them less frequent, promoting a block-like appearance of the alignment.

Delays the alignment of the most distantly related sequences until after the most closely related sequences have been aligned. The setting shows the percent identity level required to delay the addition of a sequence; sequences that are less identical than this level to any other sequences will be aligned later.
You can give a previously computed tree (.dnd file) - on the same data

There are three 'in-built' series of weight matrices offered. Each consists of several matrices which work differently at different evolutionary distances. To see the exact details, read the documentation. Crudely, we store several matrices in memory, spanning the full range of amino acid distance (from almost identical sequences to highly divergent ones). For very similar sequences, it is best to use a strict weight matrix which only gives a high score to identities and the most favoured conservative substitutions. For more divergent sequences, it is appropriate to use 'softer' matrices which give a high score to many other frequent substitutions.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.

The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.

Residue specific penalties are amino acid specific gap penalties that reduce or increase the gap opening penalties at each position in the alignment or sequence. As an example, positions that are rich in glycine are more likely to have an adjacent gap than positions that are rich in valine.
Table of residue specific gap modification factors:

The values are normalised around a mean value of 1.0 for H. The lower the value, the greater the chance of having an adjacent gap. These are derived from the original table of relative frequencies of gaps adjacent to each residue (12) by subtraction from 2.0.

Hydrophilic gap penalties are used to increase the chances of a gap within a run (5 or more residues) of hydrophilic amino acids; these are likely to be loop or random coil regions where gaps are more common. The residues that are 'considered' to be hydrophilic are set by menu item 3.

1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.

A weight of zero means that the transitions are scored as mismatches; a weight of 1 gives transitions the full match score. For distantly related DNA sequences, the weight should be near to zero; for closely related sequences it can be useful to assign a higher score.

K-TUPLE SIZE: This is the size of exactly matching fragment that is used. INCREASE for speed (max= 2 for proteins; 4 for DNA), DECREASE for sensitivity. For longer sequences (e.g. >1000 residues) you may need to increase the default.

The number of k-tuple matches on each diagonal (in an imaginary dot-matrix plot) is calculated. Only the best ones (with most matches) are used in the alignment. This parameter specifies how many. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity.
WINDOW SIZE: This is the number of diagonals around each of the 'best' diagonals that will be used. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity
This is a penalty for each gap in the fast alignments. It has little affect on the speed or sensitivity except for extreme values.
The scoring table which describes the similarity of each amino acid to each other. For DNA, an identity matrix is used.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.

The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.
For DNA, a single matrix (not a series) is used. Two hard-coded matrices are available:

1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.
In the conservation line output in the clustal format alignment file, three characters are used:
'*' indicates positions which have a single, fully conserved residue.
':' indicates that one of the following 'strong' groups is fully conserved (STA,NEQK,NHQK,NDEQ,QHRK,MILV,MILF,HY,FYW).
'.' indicates that one of the following 'weaker' groups is fully conserved (CSA,ATV,SAG,STNK,STPA,SGND,SNDEQK,NDEQHK,NEQHRK,FVLIM,HFY).
These are all the positively scoring groups that occur in the Gonnet Pam250 matrix. The strong and weak groups are defined as strong score >0.5 and weak score =<0.5 respectively.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: K-TUPLE SIZE: This is the size of exactly matching fragment that is used. INCREASE for speed (max= 2 for proteins; 4 for DNA), DECREASE for sensitivity. For longer sequences (e.g. >1000 residues) you may need to increase the default.

format.code: ( "" , " -topdiags=" + str( value ))[value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: The number of k-tuple matches on each diagonal (in an imaginary dot-matrix plot) is calculated. Only the best ones (with most matches) are used in the alignment. This parameter specifies how many. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity.

interface.label:
Number of best diagonals (-topdiags)?
The number of k-tuple matches on each diagonal (in an imaginary dot-matrix plot) is calculated. Only the best ones (with most matches) are used in the alignment. This parameter specifies how many. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The number of k-tuple matches on each diagonal (in an imaginary dot-matrix plot) is calculated. Only the best ones (with most matches) are used in the alignment. This parameter specifies how many. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity.

format.code: ( "" , " -window=" + str( value ) )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: WINDOW SIZE: This is the number of diagonals around each of the 'best' diagonals that will be used. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity

interface.label:
Window around best diags (-window)?
WINDOW SIZE: This is the number of diagonals around each of the 'best' diagonals that will be used. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: WINDOW SIZE: This is the number of diagonals around each of the 'best' diagonals that will be used. Decrease for speed; increase for sensitivity

format.code: ( "" , " -pairgap=" + str( value ))[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: This is a penalty for each gap in the fast alignments. It has little affect on the speed or sensitivity except for extreme values.

interface.label:
Gap penalty (-pairgap)?
This is a penalty for each gap in the fast alignments. It has little affect on the speed or sensitivity except for extreme values.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This is a penalty for each gap in the fast alignments. It has little affect on the speed or sensitivity except for extreme values.

format.code: ( "" , " -score=" +str( value ) )[value is not None or value != vdef]

interface.label: Percent or absolute score ? (-score) Percent Absolute

comment.text: These parameters do not have any affect on the speed of the alignments. They are used to give initial alignments which are then rescored to give percent identity scores. These % scores are the ones which are displayed on the screen. The scores are converted to distances for the trees.

format.code: ( "" , " -pwgapopen=" + str( value ) )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

interface.label: Gap opening penalty (-pwgapopen)

format.code: ( "" , " -pwgapext=" + str( value ) )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

interface.label: Gap extension penalty (-pwgapext)

format.code: ( "" , " -pwmatrix=" + str(value) )[value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: The scoring table which describes the similarity of each amino acid to each other. For DNA, an identity matrix is used.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.

The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.

interface.label:
Protein weight matrix (-pwmatrix)?
BLOSUM30 (Henikoff) Gonnet 250 PAM350 (Dayhoff) Identity matrix
The scoring table which describes the similarity of each amino acid to each other. For DNA, an identity matrix is used.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.
The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The scoring table which describes the similarity of each amino acid to each other. For DNA, an identity matrix is used.
BLOSUM (Henikoff). These matrices appear to be the best available for carrying out data base similarity (homology searches). The matrices used are: Blosum80, 62, 40 and 30.

The Gonnet Pam 250 matrix has been reported as the best single matrix for alignment, if you only choose one matrix. Our experience with profile database searches is that the Gonnet series is unambiguously superior to the Blosum series at high divergence. However, we did not get the series to perform systematically better than the Blosum series in Clustal W (communication of the authors).
PAM (Dayhoff). These have been extremely widely used since the late '70s. We use the PAM 120, 160, 250 and 350 matrices.

format.code: ( "" , " -pwdnamatrix=" + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: For DNA, a single matrix (not a series) is used. Two hard-coded matrices are available:

1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.

interface.label:
DNA weight matrix (-pwdnamatrix)?
IUB CLUSTALW
For DNA, a single matrix (not a series) is used. Two hard-coded matrices are available:
1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: For DNA, a single matrix (not a series) is used. Two hard-coded matrices are available:

1) IUB. This is the default scoring matrix used by BESTFIT for the comparison of nucleic acid sequences. X's and N's are treated as matches to any IUB ambiguity symbol. All matches score 1.9; all mismatches for IUB symbols score 0.
2) CLUSTALW(1.6). The previous system used by ClustalW, in which matches score 1.0 and mismatches score 0. All matches for IUB symbols also score 0.

format.code: ( "" , " -output=" + str( value) )[ value is not None ]

interface.label: Output format (-output) CLUSTAL FASTA GCG GDE PHYLIP PIR/NBRF NEXUS

parameter.name: seqnos
parameter.prompt: Output sequence numbers in the output file (for clustalw output only) (-seqnos)

format.code: ( "" , " -seqnos=on")[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Output sequence numbers in the output file (for clustalw output only) (-seqnos) Yes No

format.code: ( "" , " -outorder=" + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

interface.label: Result order (-outorder) Input Aligned

format.code: ( "" , " -outfile=" + str( value))[ value is not None ]

interface.label: Sequence alignment file name (-outfile)

comment.text: In the conservation line output in the clustal format alignment file, three characters are used:
'*' indicates positions which have a single, fully conserved residue.
':' indicates that one of the following 'strong' groups is fully conserved (STA,NEQK,NHQK,NDEQ,QHRK,MILV,MILF,HY,FYW).
'.' indicates that one of the following 'weaker' groups is fully conserved (CSA,ATV,SAG,STNK,STPA,SGND,SNDEQK,NDEQHK,NEQHRK,FVLIM,HFY).
These are all the positively scoring groups that occur in the Gonnet Pam250 matrix. The strong and weak groups are defined as strong score >0.5 and weak score =<0.5 respectively.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: In the conservation line output in the clustal format alignment file, three characters are used:
'*' indicates positions which have a single, fully conserved residue.
':' indicates that one of the following 'strong' groups is fully conserved (STA,NEQK,NHQK,NDEQ,QHRK,MILV,MILF,HY,FYW).
'.' indicates that one of the following 'weaker' groups is fully conserved (CSA,ATV,SAG,STNK,STPA,SGND,SNDEQK,NDEQHK,NEQHRK,FVLIM,HFY).
These are all the positively scoring groups that occur in the Gonnet Pam250 matrix. The strong and weak groups are defined as strong score >0.5 and weak score =<0.5 respectively.

interface.label: Upper case (for GDE output only) (-case) Yes No
